body: sure thing, i hope my current contribution can make it into a fix.
We're currently lacking reviewers so no PR has been merged for more than a month. Hopefully this situation will change at some point.
@danhunsaker Thanks for the review!
Now implemented those changes. CI still broken, but those seems to be problem also with other merge requests
Thank you @mlackman and @danhunsaker, merged in trunk! ✨

@pquentin @tonybaloney 
I think this PR is now mergeable.
Thank you @ZuluPro and sorry for the hassle.
Thank you @danhunsaker! Merged in trunk. ✨
Thank you, we received your ICLA. Can you please rebase your changes on top of trunk? I fixed the build issues.

Sorry for the delay, I will review the PR shortly.

Thanks for the contribution.

The changes look good to me and they have been merged into trunk :+1:

@Kami I do need help!

The issue here is that we don't want to check that the body property has been accessed, but that it has *not* been accessed. I was thinking that asserting that the property was not accessed was not robust enough, because I don't think it will help avoid a regression: many other methods are not called during the test.

What would have been interesting would be to get access to the requests Response object and check that `_content_consumed` (https://github.com/requests/requests/blob/775cde0914265d7dab2bc2501ed7abe6b85c4bae/requests/models.py#L811) is False (_content_consumed is private but really old and unlikely to change at this point).

In the context of libcloud.test.storage.test_s3.test_download_object_success I would only need to get access to the response variable defined in download_object, but I don't know how to do that.

Thoughts?
@zym-ustc Unfortunately I can't promise that somebody will look at this soon but could you please rebase off the latest trunk? Python 2.6 support has been removed.
You have a lint error left: `libcloud/compute/drivers/ecs.py:851:1: W293 blank line contains whitespace`. Please check with `tox -e lint`.
/cc @erjohnso
@Kami Any idea why we no longer have codecov reports?
For what it's worth, the pypy3 failure has nothing to do with the patch.
Thanks! Merged in trunk. ✨

@pquentin Not sure, need to have a look.
It seems like coverage reports are indeed getting uploaded to codecov, but for some reasons, coverage comments are not added to PRs.

Sorry for the delay - I was just looking into that.

You are correct, writing a test case for it is indeed quite hard - we would need to mock a lot of things, notably `HttpLibResponseProxy` and `Response`, then set `body` to `PropertyMock` and assert `call_count` attribute is 0.

I wanted to do that, but it gets really messy and error prone, because there is a lot of indirection.

For now I will go ahead and merge it into trunk and hopefully we will come up with a better way to test it in the future.

Re `_content_consumed` sadly asserting on that wont work since that variable is also set to True once content is consumed via iterator - https://github.com/requests/requests/blob/775cde0914265d7dab2bc2501ed7abe6b85c4bae/requests/models.py#L724.

Managed to come up with a test case which doesn't include too much mocking and it doesn't look too convoluted and horrible - 98a07ac377a58076e248673a55a9428c9e8dfe21.

It's still not ideal, but it's the best we can do right now and better than no tests. You can confirm it works as intended, because it will fail if you revert change / fix from this PR.
Thank you @Kami, this is great! 💯 👏

@zym-ustc I agree that those fixtures are confusing. What I can say:

 * only functions of ECSDriverTestCase that start with `test_` are considered as tests, such as test_list_nodes
 * in `ECSDriverTestCase.setUp`, the connection class of the `ECSDriver` instance is defined as `ECSMockHttp`, because we don't want to make real requests in tests, but use mocking instead
* `ECSMockHttp`, defined lower in the file, is a subclass of `MockHttp` which is defined in `libcloud/test/__init__.py` and this is where all the magic happens: when `ECSDriver` makes a request, `MockHttp._get_requests` will try to find a method in `MockHttp` to call.

For `test_list_nodes`, for example, the endpoint is `DescribeInstances`, but instead `ESMockHttp._DescribeInstances` will be called, and it only reads from the `describe_instances.xml` fixture, which is in `libcloud/test/compute/fixtures/ecs/describe_instances.xml` and this is from this file that things like `iZ28n7dkvovZ` come from.

Always make sure that your test fails without your code, and consider using a debugger such as pudb to understand what happens. So you could add `import pudb; pudb_set_trace()` in`test_list_nodes` then run `pytest -k ecs -s` and try to follow what happens. Or you can use `print()`.

Does that help?

Added a test case in 0710d23de52a1c2c4841937e4c7c17b81950b9ae and merged it into trunk.

I also included small optimization in 484e02a6395f3f05989a90b88bdb4c9b583ab4d7. Afaik, there should be no need to fall back to the `while` loop at the end of the method when iterator object has `next()` method since `next()` and `__next__()` should be equivalent.

Good catch and thanks again.

Oh, thanks @Kami! This one was easier, but for some reason I first tried the other one. I would have added the test at some point, sorry that you had to do it yourself. Your tests and changes are great, thanks.
@Kami Thanks for the review, merged in trunk.
The failure is unrelated to the PR: `pip install tox` failed.
Looks good to me, is it possible to add some kind of test case for it?

It was raising a warning on Python 3.6, it no longer is. read_in_chunks is tested by a number of tests already, the idea is that the behavior should not change. We might add 3.7-dev to the travis build matrix, but it's not feature-frozen yet so we would have to allow failures.
@pquentin I've heard it's still pretty slow on travis but it might be worth giving it a go
With all those PRs now merged, we should also start thinking about a new release (2.3.0) soon :)
Thank you for the original PR and fix :)

Sure! We have two new drivers ready for review, did you have the time to take a look?

https://github.com/apache/libcloud/pull/1121
https://github.com/apache/libcloud/pull/1154
(Travis is currently broken because the apt command is not compatible with the Ubuntu version: --force-yes is no longer supported.)

The failure does not looks related to the PR.

The failure is due to:
pip install graphviz gcc libvirt-bin

@Kami @erjohnso @supertom 
Hi,

I created a PR and the build failed.
The failure is due to:
pip install graphviz gcc libvirt-bin

I am not sure if the failure is caused due to my code changes.
Could you please help me here.
Also could you please review the code changes.
@Rahul-CSI it's not related, indeed - Travis appears to be a bit broken these days

I believe build failure is related to upstream error in libvirt package - https://travis-ci.org/apache/libcloud/jobs/326787986#L572

```Errors were encountered while processing:
 libvirt-bin
W: --force-yes is deprecated, use one of the options starting with --allow instead.
E: Sub-process /usr/bin/dpkg returned an error code (1)
```

`--force-yes` being deprecated is just a warning message and not a fatal error.
  
In short - the failure is probably related to same Travis environment / base image change.
Might be related to this - https://twitter.com/travisci/status/950481155740127232
@Kami ah yes, you're right. And yes, it's definitely related, during the migration only some of the build failed, they now all fail.
cc @erjohnso

I guess it does not hurt, but PEP 3101 does not say that formatting using the % operator should be rewritten. It even [says the opposite](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3101/#backwards-compatibility):

> Backwards compatibility can be maintained by leaving the existing mechanisms in place. The new system does not collide with any of the method names of the existing string formatting techniques, so both systems can co-exist until it comes time to deprecate the older system.

You can not say these things ***only*** according to one sentence
PEP3101 generally says .format() is a better way to formatting strings.
Well, you did edit your answer to change from "must" to "should", so I guess we agree now :)
Ehhh yes, but i still defense .format() is better idea

Looks good to me, but you might want to get eyes from someone with GCE accelerator expertise on this.

Also, take a look at http://libcloud.readthedocs.io/en/latest/development.html to make sure you are meeting libcloud's development standards.

+CC @erjohnso 
Would you please be able to take a look?
Thanks!
-alxndr@ (Cloud Graphite)
Thank you! Merged in trunk. ✨
Can you please close this pull request? Since I had to signoff the commits, GitHub does not realize it has been merged. Thanks.
Never mind, I did this differently.

I am really struggling with tests, it looks like I need to fix my python setup in order to be able to run them.

On the actual content of the tests, how do they work? They don't make real calls to the cloud, do they? How do the assert works then?

In `ex_get_subnetwork`, I think it parsed the url to be consistent with the else branch and have only one `request =` declaration. But that's just a guess.

Tests use fixtures, see https://github.com/apache/libcloud/pull/1157#issuecomment-355883772 for an explanation which uses another driver for context. For GCE, these are files like libcloud/test/compute/fixtures/gce/regions_us-central1_subnetworks_cf_972cf02e6ad49112.json.

Did you install the test requirements? Can you paste the log of `pytest -k gce` ?
Thanks, merged in trunk. ✨

Thanks @pquentin. The fixtures bit make sense. 

The requirements is where I am struggling (I have a problem with setuptools it seems), but I'll get it to work.

Are you working in a virtual environment? These instructions should work:

```
python3 -m venv myvenv
source myvenv/bin/activate
pip install -r requirements-tests.txt
pytest -k gce
```

The last command should print this:

```
========================= test session starts ==========================
platform darwin -- Python 3.6.3, pytest-3.3.1, py-1.5.2, pluggy-0.6.0
rootdir: /Users/quentin/Projects/libcloud, inifile: pytest.ini
collected 8995 items

libcloud/test/compute/test_gce.py .............................. [ 15%]
................................................................ [ 48%]
................................................................ [ 82%]
..................                                               [ 91%]
libcloud/test/loadbalancer/test_gce.py ................          [100%]

======================== 8803 tests deselected =========================
============= 192 passed, 8803 deselected in 22.08 seconds =============
```
Thanks a lot for that! It worked, unlike all the other solutions so far.

thanks again @pquentin for the advice, I got the tests working and added simple tests for URLs passing in `get_network` and `get_subnetwork`. Let me know what you think, and if you had more in mind.

I also updated the doc of `get_network`.

Thanks! Those tests are useful. However you're only testing with the correct project name, that is you're only testing the old behavior. This is nice! We did not have such a test until now. But we need to test the new behavior too, by using an URL with a different project name. I'll guess you'll need a new fixture. Maybe something like:

```
url = 'https://www.googleapis.com/compute/v1/projects/other_name/regions/us-central1/subnetworks/cf-972cf02e6ad49112'
subnetwork = self.driver.ex_get_subnetwork(url)
self.assertEqual(subnetwork.name, name)
self.assertEqual(subnetwork.region.name, region_name)
```
and
```
def _projects_other_name_regions_us_central1_subnetworks_cf_972cf02e6ad49112(self, method, url, body, headers):
    body = self.fixtures.load(
        'regions_us-central1_subnetworks_cf_972cf02e6ad49112.json')
    return (httplib.OK, body, self.json_hdr, httplib.responses[httplib.OK])
```

(You need `_projects_other_name` in the method name, see GCEMockHttp._get_method_name in libcloud/test/compute/test_gce.py.)

And you will need to do the same thing for networks.
you're right, I need to cover the shared network situation. I'll update the tests.
I've added tests with networks and subnetworks that are declared under a different project, assuming that the 'loaded' project always is `project_name`.
Thanks! Merged in trunk. ✨

Just FYI, this PR seems to implement the "old" API (https://robot.your-server.de/doc/webservice/en.html). There is also a newer "cloud" API (https://docs.hetzner.cloud/) that allows a more programmatic approach to managing servers (AFAICT it's not possible to create a server using the old API). However, the newer API seems to be limited to the newer cloud products, i.e.: it doesn't seem to be able to manage the bare-metal servers.
